title: High MS in our local area
body:
Hello! The issue I'm experiencing seems to extreme increase in ping (ms) in our local area. I asked around in (northwest ohio) and everyone I've spoken with has said the same thing. All of their pings have gone up from ~20 to 60-90. I've called our local ISP (Buckeye Cable System) to no avail.

Edit: I have done some more research and found this in my trace route to the riot servers:

traceroute to 104.160.131.1 (104.160.131.1), 30 hops max, 38 byte packets
 **1**  10.24.0.1 (10.24.0.1)  20.000 ms  10.000 ms  20.000 ms
 **2**  72.240.7.61 (72.240.7.61)  20.000 ms  20.000 ms  20.000 ms
 **3**  72.240.111.29 (72.240.111.29)  20.000 ms  72.240.111.33 (72.240.111.33)  20.000 ms  72.240.111.29 (72.240.111.29)  10.000 ms
 **4**  72.240.111.49 (72.240.111.49)  20.000 ms  30.000 ms  20.000 ms
 **5**  te-4-3.car2.Detroit1.Level3.net (4.53.74.101)  110.000 ms  110.000 ms  110.000 ms

It would seem that the drastic increase in ping occurs in line 5, the "te-4-3.car2.Detroit1.Level3.net" 
I have no clue about networking, so I ended up calling my IPS (Buckeye Cable System) again for the 4th time today. Unfortunately, they seem to know even less than me... I ended up emailing riots peering team in hopes that they could work with my ISP to find a solution. (not likely). If anyone has any ideas on how to help, don't hesitate to send me a private message or leave a comment.

replies.body:
Latency (ping) in a local area is typically caused by an issue with a local node or handoff prior to your connection hitting our servers. To investigate this, we'll need to look at a traceroute log, which you can run using [WinMTR](http://winmtr.net/). After booting up the app, plug **104.160.131.1** into the host field before starting the trace. After ~5 minutes has passed by, export the result as text and paste them in a reply to me.

Let me know if you run into any issues running that trace.

Thanks for providing this log! Just as in your previous trace, this one shows the same hike in latency at the following node:

> **te-4-3.car2.Detroit1.Level3.net**

Since your ISP partners with Level 3 (the owner of this node), I'd recommend reaching back out to your ISP and specifically request a tier 2 agent or a supervisor before providing this traceroute to them. This should provide additional context they need to launch a proper investigation for this issue.

Let me know if you have any other questions.

Hello, I've attempted to reach out the my local ISP (Buckeye Cable) about the Level 3 Node dropping packets multiple times. Unfortunately they refusing to help with this issue. I was wondering if there way possibly some way a Riot Games representative/technician would be able to get in contact with them to address this issue. I'm unsure as to how many users are being routed through "te-4-3.car2.Detroit1.Level3.net", but I can't imagine this is the first you guys have heard of this issue. 

Thanks in advance! A speedy response would be greatly appreciated! {{item:3073}}

Unfortunately, we are unable to contact your ISP or their partners on your behalf. In my experience, it can take multiple points of contact or escalations to higher levels of support before a solution can be met.

I'm sorry that I'm unable to assist further at this point, but please let me know if you have any other questions.
